title: The Knoll
author: Philip J. LaMantia
summary:
There lives a man atop the Knoll,
Whose greasy fingers seek control;
As days go past, the man yearns for more,
Leaving h...
content:
There lives a man atop the Knoll,
Whose greasy fingers seek control;
As days go past, the man yearns for more,
Leaving his home to wander and spread his spores.
In villages he finds the ones in need,
And offering kind help, he plants the seed.
Then they find in their homes a creeping hold
A plant, a vine, a spore becoming mold.

The man returns to his forested abode,
Seeking some comfort, he finds his sickly toad.
The toad cries out, “Now let me go, I plea;
No longer do I want this grassbed home for me!”
The man grows angry and rumples at its nose;
Thus, the toad falls silent, working on its prose.

The Knoll seeks more its grasses growing hungry;
The man feeds it each day with gathered twigs dumbly.
It rumbles loud as colder nights draw near;
So he lies down with it and calls it dear.
The toad then creaks a ribbit filled with fear,
“Please, I implore you now; O lend your ear.
The Knoll is feeding on your lonely mind;
Go to the village, step outside.
In your absence I shall cleanse your home;
The Knoll will shrink, becoming a clean biome.”

The man then laughed at toad’s simple plea;
He knew the Knoll was the worst of any flea.
Yet left the home in hopes the toad was right
That such a creature small could mount a fight.
The days passed on; the toad stayed locked within,
Its throat clogged thick by workings of the Djinn.
Yet it prevailed though nearing its last breath
The Knoll now clean and void of the lethe.

As toad drifted to sleep, the man returned,
Holding a pot with brand new fronds newly un-fern’d.
Though frog had tried, the man contained the stain
A piece of Knoll embedded deep in his brain.
Thus fern took hold and gave the Knoll a path back;
The toad cried out, its lungs burst with spore-filled sacs.

title: A Squire and A Knight
author: Philip J. LaMantia
summary:
Squire and Knight rode miles together.
The Knight, worn thin, still carried steady flame.
The squire watched him, light ...
content: Squire and Knight rode miles together. The Knight, worn thin, still carried steady flame. The squire watched him, light as a feather. “Where do we ride today?”, the squire asked. “My final place. The ground that bears my name.” The squire shrieked in fear, his master now departing. “Who will I learn from whence you are gone? Still full of wisdom left for imparting. Let me die first, for the world will not miss me.” “It will, for it is your time to be called-on” “Then, it is not your teachings but your amity I require. Watch me live as you taught, So I don't suffer grave calamity.” A crow landed on the middle road. “I want nothing more. For this I am wrought.” “Who will find me when I am lost and scared? Or pick me up and guide my way back home? There is more I need, I am lost, Impaired!” The Knight looked stoically straight ahead. “Fear not, for your heart bears my final tome.”

title: aurora
author: Walter J. Kinder

of mountains and tributaries 
and beyond it, that Canadian

content:
Pale pearl paint bled-through with ranges
of mountains and tributaries 
and beyond it, that Canadian
or Appalachian, Nordic, and Siberian.
A heavy axe leaned by a heavy door
meets the soft callus of a sleepy morning-hand
wood burns then, in a stove of stone,
as the aurora shy, starts to sing
and the snow warm starts to fall.

title: Burn
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
You sit there
or stand
Worrying about worrying
Anxious
about what you’re so sure
will come to be

And maybe
I foresee
th...
content:
You sit there
or stand
Worrying about worrying
Anxious
about what you’re so sure
will come to be

And maybe
I foresee
the same

We walk here
or run
Careful about caring
Waiting
for these things to leave
for friendship

And maybe
I want
the same

But I know
this cannot stay;
that when I wake
you’re on me.

But you know
this cannot stay;
that when you wake
I’m in you.

And we lay
But feet apart
Reaching and hoping
for the other to give

Maybe it’s too real.
for you –  
And it’s probably too real.
for me –

And then, we lay
together, then apart
pulling and pushing
testing the tie

Maybe it’s too real –
No, that’s what it is;
we’ve pulled enough
and it hasn’t snapped

And we both know
this cannot stay
that when we wake
you’re on me

And I’m in you.

We walk around, here
night after night
day after day
Let’s quit the hoping
and stop the waiting

Let’s wake
like we’ve been wanting
and if we burn

We burn.

title: Series of Dreams II
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
And later, they wake
         	From their Series of Dreams
 As breaths taken miles away
         	Feel like kisses on th...
content:
And later, they wake
         	From their Series of Dreams
 As breaths taken miles away
         	Feel like kisses on their skin.

        	They cannot see each other
         	Even though they look.
                     	They cannot hear each other
                     	Even though they listen.

And always, outside
         	Puddles sit on the sidewalk
 As yellow surrounds green
         	While the sun hides away.

        	They cannot hold each other
         	Yet, they are not cold.
                     	They cannot grasp each other
                     	Yet they know they’re there.

On and on, they go
         	For the water dances with the wind
 The green grows at the center
         	And the sun can still be found.

                                	They need not hold each other
                                 	Soon, they will be warm,
                                             	And as they long, as they reach
                                             	They know, it’s all worthwhile.

                                                                Forever they’ll live
                                                         	And ever they’ll wait.

                                                                    	And as they lay to rest,
                                                                    	They are longing to live,
                                                                                	
                                                                                	Their Series of Dreams

title: The Swamp Man
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
Way in the woods
 Surrounded by swamps
 Is a bungalow
 With a roof made of dirt
 Walls made of sand
 And a floor of mud
...
content:
Way in the woods
 Surrounded by swamps
 Is a bungalow
 With a roof made of dirt
 Walls made of sand
 And a floor of mud
 It has no door
 no windows
 and inside, the same:
 no keys anywhere
 for nowhere, in there
 are there any locks.

In the bungalow
 lives a lonely man
 And everyday
 And every night
 Mothers, from the nearest town
 Fathers and sons, on the road
 Faceless passerby
 And friendly bygones
 Come by
 Some for minutes
 Some for hours
 On their own volition.

With this man
 They open their hearts
 Spill their minds
 And empty their souls.
 And to them
 He gives ears
 He gives eyes
 He gives space
 And, he gives time
 And, he stays,
 never diverging
 until they are done.

And, when they do leave
 And there’s a moment’s rest
 The man lays in the mud
 and he cries.

title: Shark
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
Even with the oncoming sun
 and the spring it brings
 along with the snow, melting
 turned to soft slush
 making nice pu...
content:
Even with the oncoming sun
 and the spring it brings
 along with the snow, melting
 turned to soft slush
 making nice puddles for jumping
 and filling the rivers
 for swimming.

Even then:
 with the new enlightenment
 and its sound wisdoms
 along with the new rhythm
 blowing sax and singing soul
 slinging sweet symphonies
 and beating the bell.

How,
 amongst the wiring
 and amid the welding 
 which craft frames
 and draw schematics
 does this all seem
 like semantics?

How, then
 submerged in this salt
 floating along the flotsam
 which, rotting
 smells like a memory
 Seldom lived
 and often remembered?

Maybe, then
 this ardent zeal
 is blasphemous bloat
 tacked on and taped
 to entice the big snake
 that it’s better to sleep
 than to slither.

Or, maybe,
 There isn’t a sheen
 But a sheet of sheens
 and those already passed
 in the past, should stay
 and some select others
 are saved solely for God.


Can you hear me?
 Wherever you are?
 I tell you –
 and it’s all gone

Do you agree?
 how seamless
 and simply strange
 dreams are?

Does your reality
 destabilize and estrange
 blending into dreams
 and blending forth from them?

Is boredom so terrible?
 Relative to hunger?
 Relative to loneliness?
 You’d rather have nothing?

And then
 as the fuselage explodes
 do you imagine
 being stranded at sea?

Floating along
 with shark passerby
 and gulls overhead
 all alone


To then be collected
 and be returned
 so people celebrate
 your own name?

You parents’ embrace
 A friend’s kiss
 and a lover’s touch
 the ocean far away

Do you, then
 wish it were closer
 imagine, then
 you were sailing once again?


Later, can you imagine
 on your death bed
 flowers on the table
 your family gone

The room all white
 Reeking with nothing
 and visiting hours
 not scheduled until later

Can you think?
 what is later.
 when is it?
 and why, then, do you even care?

Can you hear me?
 Because you will
 Dying and alone, you’ll wish
 You were sailing at sea

You will, then
 wish things were closer
 and imagine, then
 you were sailing once again.

title: Selfless
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
Across the stars
 never has there been
 and never will there be
 something quite like this

One moment, it’s day
 The ne...
content:
Across the stars
 never has there been
 and never will there be
 something quite like this

One moment, it’s day
 The next, it’s night
 Miss the sunset
 and miss the between.

In its reality
 It’s become unreal
 To that, at home
 and its gentle hold

So gentle
 and so warm.

Remember this
 and hunt for it
 try to hold on
 - never will it pass again

One moment, it’s day
 The next, it’s night
 Miss the sunset
 and miss the between.

In its reality
 It’s become unreal
 From there, the home
 and all you’ve ever known

So gentle
 and so warm.

From this and the next
 Forevermore, it’s gone
 Search for the spirit
 Sated, this will never be

One moment, it’s day
 The next, it’s night
 Miss the sunset
 And miss the between

In its reality
 It’s become unreal
 To that, the heart
 So carefully cared for

So gentle
 and so warm.

Across the stars
 never has there been
 and never will there be
 anything quite like this.

One moment, it’s day
 The next, it’s night
 Missing the sunset
 We’ve missed the between.

In its reality
 It’s become unreal
 To that, the mind
 and all we now know.

So gentle
 and so warm.

So gentle
 that we wish we were
 So warm
 all that’s gone wrong.

So gentle, and so warm,
 that we wish we were
 So gentle, and so warm,
 All we know we’re not.

title: Snap
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
How long will I rot
 until I leap from this bog
 - until I realize
 I can indeed smell
 the stinking smog
 and I can ind...
content:
How long will I rot
 until I leap from this bog
 - until I realize
 I can indeed smell
 the stinking smog
 and I can indeed read
 the bloody writing
 sprayed on every building
 etched into every brick
 and shining in the oil
 flooding every parking lot
 and built from the bodies
 filling every city ditch;
 cut into our faces
 and scarred into our thighs
 burned into our bottles
 and scabbed into our scalps
 poisoning our minds
 and infesting our gods
 bastardizing our sons
 and damming our daughters
 and, everywhere else
 written on every wallowing wall.
 How long, will I rot?
 until I realize
 I can, with my own eyes
 unfettered, indeed
 and unfiltered
 unbiased
 and with unaimed prejudice
see all this for what it is.

How long will I rot
 until, from what I know
 I finally act
 How long, will we rot?
 until we finally decide -
 from all we feel from the forests
 and from what we’ve derived
 for so long
 from the deserts;
 from all the skies have said -
 not what’s been contrived
 but what they’ve screamed
 for centuries;
 from all the blood we’ve spilt
 and from the wars we’ve waged
 for no other reason
 than that’s all we know;
 from all the science has shown -
 not that which we’ve decided
 but that, to it
 we’ve assigned truth;
 and from our faiths
 all and one; one and all
 and from our passions
 all and one; one and all
 do we finally decide
 we must make something else.

If it must be
 then let it be a war
 if it must
 then why wait for the war?

A war
 with the forest’s wishes
 and the sky’s blessings.
 A war
 where the blood shed
 is not red
 but black;
 where the science
 ceases to be
 A war
 where our faiths
 and where our passions
 bring down not buildings
 but blow up how little
 we’ve managed to imagine
 A war, not final
 but to begin anew.

How long, must we rot
 until we realize
 we must do it ourselves?

author: Walter J. Kinder

We were never where we were supposed to be
 We never knew

 now, I know

content:
We were never where we were supposed to be
 We never knew
 and never cared
 now, I know
 and now, I care

 I wish
 we could go together.

title: Epilogue
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
They’re those left behind;
 those expected yet neglected.
 Forced to douse their lamps
 and made to sail us through the ...
content:
They’re those left behind;
 those expected yet neglected.
 Forced to douse their lamps
 and made to sail us through the seas.

Unto them, were instilled storms:
 beaten out of them, were their bones
 sucked from them, were their souls
 Lulled away, was their love.

We’re underdecks
 we’re off hidden in the dark.
 Against their arms, are the oars
 as they bear the brunt of the winds.

The acidic rain’s sulfuric;
 it’s raking and tearing at their flesh.
 The rotting bread’s wet;
 scattered, the rats hoard the crumbs.

The frozen winds howl;
 it’s eroding at their skulls.
 The black waves bring sickness;
 a few more have drowned away.

Muffled their voices are
 shouting and calling through the planks –
 through their welded muzzles
 and sewn-shut hoods.

Stumbling over every swell
 Is our odyssey doomed.
 Down here, a few drops leak through
 So few, are those piercing the net.

The storms are perfect
 in our science and design:
 they’re beyond atomic;
 their fallout will be everlasting.

They’ll eventually leave
 having succumbed to the storm:
 they’ll be sentenced to the sea
 face-up, or face-down.

We’re underdecks
 we’re off hidden in the dark.
 And we’ve our own lamps
 and we’ll have grown enough food.

 There are so few galleons, now
 and the little leaks are so many
 is nobody left
 to sail our sinking ship?

To our odyssey doomed
 Has our storm
 Really killed
 All who could’ve landed her?

 Where have they gone?
 Those that would have?
 With solely a spoon
 Those that would have?

title: mediocre song
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
My addictive friend
 shivers in the summer.
 It whimpers as you sing
 and itches as ears ring.

I’m a turnstile
 slappin...
content:
My addictive friend
 shivers in the summer.
 It whimpers as you sing
 and itches as ears ring.

I’m a turnstile
 slapping right to left
 and lurching back again
 between this vice
 and that well-worn tune
 with its weathered notes
 and whose melody
 was never that good
 anyway.

My addiction
 shivers in the summer.
 Please, one more time sing
 so I may feel that ring.

I’m a workhorse
 trudging from here to there
 and lurching back again
 between this task
 and my newest obligation
 with its tired rhythms
 and whose steps
 remind me awfully
 of my old music.

I, alone
 shiver in the summer.
 I’ll bury it under anything
 so my ears don’t ring.

Please, one more time, sing
 Sing for me
 So I may hear that ring

title: For S-
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
Friend
 who’s tired and sad
 Trying so hard to seem hard
 There’s respite in us
 and you may not show it
 but I know you...
content:
Friend
 who’s tired and sad
 Trying so hard to seem hard
 There’s respite in us
 and you may not show it
 but I know you know
 and this, you know too.

My friend,
 you spend the night taking.
 You’re so scared of sharing
 from you, so much was stolen
 and when you reached out last
 open-handed
 you were beaten down again.

Friend
 you hide yourself
 like you’ve always done
 and these people you take from
 and those taking from you
 likely, they’ll never know
 you’ve even a mask.

My friend,
 you’re too stubborn to stop
 and too stuck-in to ask
 May you find someone
 who, against your shell
 will bring a shovel
 and you may share with them
 that which you always were.

title: beautiful baby
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
My beautiful baby
 Hands on the pavement
 and feet in the grass
 Eyes tied shut
 And hair let down
 its bright waves gol...
content:
My beautiful baby
 Hands on the pavement
 and feet in the grass
 Eyes tied shut
 And hair let down
 its bright waves gold
 falling over your shoulders
 and settling
 just past your breast
 When you turn away
 And, head high
 Eyes open, then
 And your fingers feeling
 Keep going
 and don’t ever stop.
 When, after the storm,
 the grass tickles your toes
 And, when,
 after the drought
 it scratches your skin
 let it burn
 and let it melt
 Let it all come apart
 until your ashes
 swept up
 by that sudden wind
 blow away
 until all that’s left
 is scattered all over
 by that little lightly hue
 and still;
 let it burn
 and let it melt
 But please
 My beautiful baby
 don’t ever
 not even for a thought
 begin back down that way
 that took everything
 and abandon this:
 these gifts
 of something.

title: tablecloth
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
Across the tablecloth
 I foresee what will be said;
 I know what’s been shared
 and i even
 relate
 to you

And I say no...
content:
Across the tablecloth
 I foresee what will be said;
 I know what’s been shared
 and i even
 relate
 to you

And I say nothing
 No words your way
 just expressions
 diluted and reserved
 muted
 muzzled

I used to wait for a question
 To which, I’d answer
 But now, that’s gone
 I hold back
 deeming it simple
 too easy

At this table
 I don’t make it ours
 I leave it yours
 only waiting
 to leave

I lay
 and wish I spoke
 I could and I can
 but, I’m back there
 and i long to leave again.

title: a firefly
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
I tell you this
 in doing so
 I adhere to my heart.
 All those things I’ve offered
 the suggestions and lessons
 that yo...
content:
I tell you this
 in doing so
 I adhere to my heart.
 All those things I’ve offered
 the suggestions and lessons
 that you’ve adopted
 and have, I think,
 healed with –
 I validate.
 I live truthfully
 through my dogma
 I’ve so zealously
 enticed you to.

I tell you this
 and I’m not a hypocrite.
 I do this thing
 and
 it’ll be me
 following my heart
 that droning machine
 clicking on every hour
 rimming through the night
 I’d be unplugging it
 soothing that itch
 you so easily
 just like every time
 before
 enflamed.

I tell you this
 and everything’s back on
 we’re back on the track
 running our miles;
 walking with our moon
 and fishing our creeks.
 Once more, that fox,
 will sit before us
 and cock its head
 as those fireflies
 mate in the night.

I
 don’t
 tell you this
 and you keep your picture:
 you keep your pretty smile
 and all I’ve given you
 you
 get to keep;
 I don’t tell you
 and I’m left with that
 machine
 which I’ll leave
 when I finally sail away.

title: Swamp Man II
author: Walter J. Kinder
summary:
He’s left his swamp
 and his bank in the road
 behind him, are his passerby
 before him, now
 are the sleepless.

He wai...
content:
He’s left his swamp
 and his bank in the road
 behind him, are his passerby
 before him, now
 are the sleepless.

He waits
 and they reach out
 and he gives a finger
 and then a hand
 and then his head.

And he returns
 to his tower
 bricks and shingles
 leaving open his blinds
 and his door.

He's gone on too long
 Too proficient are his lies
 Too convincing
 is his face
 No one ever says hello.
